content:
This article explores the need for an intermediate CSS unit between root and relative values, proposing a new concept called "base" units like bem (base em) and blh (base line-height).

Current CSS units fall into two categories:

  • Root values (e.g., rem, rlh) tied to the :root selector (commonly the html element).
  • Relative values (e.g., em, lh, ch) tied to the font-size of the specific element they are applied to.

The author argues that a unit referencing a specific element's font size, but acting as a base for its children, would simplify styling, especially for typographic rhythm and component spacing.

Two primary examples illustrate the problem:

  • Prose example: Using 1lh for margins in a .prose class breaks down when typography of different sizes is introduced, as 1lh becomes disproportionately large. While Flexbox with gap can help, it leads to proximity confusion, requiring more complex margin adjustments.
  • Card component example: Applying lh for padding within a card with a different header font size causes the header's margin to become excessively large. Using rlh is also problematic when the card needs to scale to different font sizes.

The proposed "base" units (bem and blh) would allow elements to inherit a defined font size from a specific parent, simplifying calculations for padding, margins, and other spacing.

Potential implementation methods discussed include:

  • Container Queries: Introducing units like cqbem or cqlh, though this requires defining containers and can lead to collisions.
  • Anchor Positioning Syntax: Explicitly defining a base-anchor or base-name for elements to inherit values from.

The article also provides a practical, albeit more verbose, workaround using CSS variables and calc() that can be implemented today, along with suggestions for abstracting this into Sass mixins or Tailwind utilities. The author also mentions a library called "Splendid Styles" that offers pre-built solutions.

The author seeks community feedback on the concept of these intermediate units, the proposed names bem and blh, and whether this design aspect is overthought.
